contentrichtext.text: {{Orphan|date=September 2011}} In [[mathematics]], a '''quasi-topology''' on a set ''X'' is a function that associates to every [[compact space|compact]] [[Hausdorff space]] ''C'' a collection of mappings from ''C'' to ''X'' satisfying certain natural conditions. A set with a quasi-topology is called a '''quasitopological space''' They were introduced by Spanier, who showed that there is a natural quasi-topology on the space of continuous maps from one space to another. ==References== *{{citation|last=Spanier|first=E.|authorlink=Edwin Spanier|title=Quasi-topologies|journal=Duke Mathematical Journal|volume=30|issue=1|year=1963|pages=1â€“14|doi=10.1215/S0012-7094-63-03001-1|mr=0144300}}.
